DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US holds off on decision regarding Huawei licenses following China suspension of agricultural purchases. (Newswires)

Global Times Editor said trade war has greatly squeezed pro-US thoughts inside China, making it easier for the Communist Party to unite Chinese society, while he added that China is not the Soviet Union and as long as it keeps political stability, economic vitality of China will be unleashed constantly. Furthermore, he also noted that encouraging China trade data shows China enterprises are adjusting as well as creating new export markets, and that a "trade war won't crush China". (Twitter) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said Parliament should honour the Brexit vote and leave on October 31st, while he is hopeful and confident that the EU will show flexibility and a willingness to compromise. PM Johnson responded that he is committed to delivering on the Brexit vote when asked about early elections and reiterated there is a good deal to be done once there is change to the backstop issue. In related news, UK PM Johnson reportedly will hold a general election days after the Brexit if he is forced to go to polls by a no-confidence vote. (Newswires/FT)

Italy Deputy PM and League leader Salvini said there is no longer a majority to support the government and it is necessary to hold fresh elections, while he told PM Conte it is a necessity to formalize the current crisis in Parliament and the League Party earlier stated the only alternative to the current government is new elections as they do not want a reshuffle of the cabinet and rejects the idea of technical governance. There were also reports that League are ready for a confidence vote as soon as next week, while Deputy PM Di Maio that he is ready for elections and that Salvini will pay for taking Italy for a ride. (Newswires)

There were initial reports that Germany is considering a U-turn in fiscal policy and considering issuance of new debt to finance climate production in which it will link new issuance to climate measures to ensure budget floodgates are not opened up, although Germany later stated there is no decision to give up the balanced budget

 

FX

All Central Bank of Turkey general managers appointed during the term of former Governor Çetinkaya were dismissed by the Bank's Assembly. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi official said they plan to keep August production below 10mln BPD (July production stood at 9.65mln BPD) and are committed to do whatever it takes to keep the oil market balanced. The official added that August oil nominations were 700k BPD above July which is a sign of healthy demand and September nominations will fall by 700k BPD from August levels, while they plan to keep exports below 7mln BPD in its August and September. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said they remain committed to the OPEC and non-OPEC agreement, which has brought greater market balance and improved market stability, while they will continue to support actions which balance the oil market and he is confident OPEC/NON-OPEC members will take a similar stance. (Newswires)

ICE is raising margin requirements for ICE Futures US Oil Contract, effective from the close of business on August 12th and which will be reflected in margin calls made the next day. (ICE)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that Iran is in serious financial trouble and they want to talk to the US, but they are given mixed signals from all of those purporting to represent us including French President Macron. (Twitter)

 

US

US President Trump reiterated his stance against the Fed in which he stated that a high USD is making it harder for manufacturers such as Caterpillar, Boeing and auto makers. (Twitter)

 

MARKET RECAP

Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) was over 15% higher after it introduced its new Epyc server chip, which the chipmaker claims to be twice as fast as Intel’s (INTC) Cascade Lake Chip; INTC were initially lower by around 1%, however, as markets gained the stock clawed back losses and closed 1% higher; Altice (ATUS) was pressured in late trade as talks with Stonepeak reportedly collapsed, with regards to the selling of its stake in Lightpath. Sarapeta Therapeutics (SRPT) were hit after it was revealed in an FDA statement its SRP-1001 drug had safety issues. Symantec (SYMC) spiked over 10% with Broadcom (AVGO) close to acquiring the company, AVGO were initially lower by over 1% but closed positive. Viacom (VIAB) had earnings where they beat on both EPS and revenue, however, when asked about the CBS merger in the conference call, the co. did not comment despite source reports earlier in the week stating further announcements could be seen in the conference call. Elsewhere, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) completed its acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum (APC) and Kraft Heinz (KHC) reported Q2 earnings which beat expectations; however, the packaged foods maker was as it disclosed another USD 1.2bln write-down, adding to the USD 15bln charge it took earlier in the year. S&P 500 1.9% AT 2938, NASDAQ-100 2.3% AT 7725, DJIA 1.4% AT 26381.

Trade wars, low inflation, and commentary suggesting neutral rates may be lower than previously seen has been driving the rally in bonds this week, but the rally paused on Thursday after the PBOC overnight weakened the yuan fix by less than models had suggested. The curve was bear steepening in early trade, and yields saw further upside in sympathy with EGBs, on reports that Germany was mulling raising issuance; the report was denied by the Germans, and the Bund gradually pared back the knee-jerk downside. The US sold 30-year bonds sold at 2.335%, tailing 1.2bps. Cover picked up from the prior, and came in in line with recent averages; dealer participation fell from the prior, though was a touch short t=of the recent average; direct participation fell versus the prior, but was still short of the six auction averages. Indirect participation recovered to above 60%, rising from the prior and above recent averages. After the auction, T-Note futures continued rose, though still end the day with yields higher across the curve (2s +4bps, 5s +3.4bps, 10s +2.6bps, 30s +4.4bps). US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks lower 129-29+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th August 2019: Bond rally pauses, stocks rise
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 8th August 2019: Bond rally pauses, stocks rise.

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar flat, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Bond rally pauses for breath; PBOC fixes CNY above 7 for the first time since 2008; Germany mulls fiscal U-turn; June wholesale inventories revised lower; Italy govt on verge of collapse.

* COMING UP: Data: Japanese GDP, Chinese & US PPI, German Trade Balance, UK GDP (Estimate/Prelim), Services, Industrial & Manufacturing Output, Canadian Building Permits & Jobs Data, Speakers: RBA’s Lowe, Earnings: Novo Nordisk.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Wednesday’s bond rally, which saw yields in major markets collapse, stabilised on Thursday, though has not pared Wednesday’s moves; though the PBOC weakened its yuan reference point overnight, was it not as much as some models had implied, which gave encouragement to market participants, as did China trade data. Perhaps bonds have been assisted by the rise in crude, where the Saudis appear to be discussing measures with international partners to stabilise the crude market and will reportedly not tolerate a continued slide in oil prices. There is a disjointed feel to markets: havens still retain their bid, despite firmer equities; however, the Treasury curve has yields higher across the board.

* CNY: China’s central bank weakened the yuan reference point, fixing it above 7.00 against the USD for the first time since 2008, although was not weakened as much as some models had foreseen. The market has been eying the fix for insight on what constitutes a ‘comfortable’ level for the PBOC. UBS notes that although the PBOC has stepped up measures to slow the yuan’s pace of depreciation (including: introducing a larger counter cyclical factor, issuing central bank bills in Hong Kong to manage liquidity, pledging to keep the yuan stable) the market remain concerned about further weakening. “Today’s fixing is a clear message that China doesn’t mind letting its currency depreciate beyond any specific number, but would like to control the pace it weakens and mitigate market volatility as ‘stability’, which is PBoC governor Yi Gang's main goal.” The bank believes that upward pressure on USDCNH is likely to persist in the near-term.

* CHINA TRADE: The trade surplus narrowed, but the pace of export growth rose unexpectedly in July on the back of stronger exports to non-US nations. Declining exports to the US moderated a slightly, but analysts still suggest that this implies that the drag from US Tariffs continued to intensify. The decline of imports also was better than expected, which CapEco says is consistent with evidence that headwinds to the domestic economy eased. “Looking ahead, exports still look set to remain under pressure in the coming quarters as any prop from a weaker renminbi should be overshadowed by further US tariffs and broader external weakness,” according to Capital Economics, “though August exports may benefit from front-loading before the new tariffs go into effect on September 1st, this bump will probably be smaller than it was ahead of earlier rounds of tariffs as US port storage facilities have little spare capacity.” The consultancy does not think that the recent fiscal easing will be enough to prevent a renewed slowdown in domestic demand, which will likely weigh on import volumes.

* GERMANY FISCAL U-TURN: Germany is reportedly considering a fiscal policy U-turn, possibly jettisoning its balanced budget goal, and mulls new debt to finance climate production spending. The report stated that Berlin will link the new issuance to climate measures, in order to ensure that ensure the "budget floodgates" are not opened up. The exact amount of issuance will be known once German Chancellor Merkel's climate protection package, which will be unveiled next month. The German government declined to comment on the report, and a spokesperson later said that there no decision had yet been taken on giving up a balanced budget.

* US JUNE WHOLESALE INVENTORIES: There was an unexpected downward revision to wholesale inventories in June. Goldman Sachs said the data shifted the composition of growth from the second to the third quarter, and accordingly, it lowered its past-quarter GDP tracking estimate for Q2 by one tenth to +1.9% (qoq ar, compared to +2.1% as originally reported) but boosted its Q3 GDP tracking estimate by the same amount, also to +1.9%.

* ITALY: The Bund/BTP spread widened to over 210bps on Thursday, after the League Party threatened to quit the coalition government. League’s Salvini said it is now necessary to hold fresh elections as there is no longer a majority to support the government. 5SM’s Di Maio responded saying they are ready for elections and Salvini will pay for taking Italy for a ride. Frictions between the League and the anti-establishment Five Star Movement party have escalated in recent hours, Stratfor reported, leading to rumours that the League may leave the government, or at least demand a Cabinet reshuffle to increase its influence on policy. There is some focus on the economy minister Tria, who is seen as a moderate technocrat, amid rumours the League want him sacked. The League’s withdrawal from the government would not necessarily lead to an early general election, as Italian President Sergio Mattarella is likely to ask the parties in Parliament to appoint a new government before deciding to hold an early election, Stratfor said; The President has been keen for the 2020 budget preparations to proceed, in order that it can be presented to lawmakers in October.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLES 7+ TICKS LOWER 129-29+. Trade wars, low inflation, and commentary suggesting neutral rates may be lower than previously seen has been driving the rally in bonds this week, but the rally paused on Thursday after the PBOC overnight weakened the yuan fix by less than models had suggested. The curve was bear steepening in early trade, and yields saw further upside in sympathy with EGBs, on reports that Germany was mulling raising issuance; the report was denied by the Germans, and the Bund gradually pared back the knee-jerk downside. The US sold 30-year bonds sold at 2.335%, tailing 1.2bps. Cover picked up from the prior, and came in in line with recent averages; dealer participation fell from the prior, though was a touch short t=of the recent average; direct participation fell versus the prior, but was still short of the six auction averages. Indirect participation recovered to above 60%, rising from the prior and above recent averages. After the auction, T-Note futures continued rose, though still end the day with yields higher across the curve (2s +4bps, 5s +3.4bps, 10s +2.6bps, 30s +4.4bps)

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson may hold General Election day after Brexit on 1st November, The Sun reported. The plan would allow Johnson to tell voters he has delivered Brexit. Aides reportedly think that holding a vote hours after the UK has quit Europe would give the Conservatives a boost from Leave voters. The news follows suggestions that opposition leader Corbyn is preparing to hit Johnson with a no confidence vote as soon as Parliament returns in September. Later, UK Foreign Minister Raab reiterates UK will leave EU in October, government would prefer to leave with a deal, but if EU is not flexible, UK will leave on WTO terms.

* WTI (U9) SETTLES USD 1.45 HIGHER AT USD 52.54/BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 1.15 HIGHER AT USD 57.38: Oil prices were firmer on Thursday, with the market finding support after a bout of excessive selling. The bounce was catalysed not long after the energy settlement on Wednesday, when comments from Saudi Arabia suggested the OPEC kingpin is considering all options to stabilise the oil market. Earlier on Thursday, a Saudi official doubled down, saying it is willing to do “whatever it takes” to keep the market balanced, and jawboned that the Kingdom is seeing healthy demand and that concerns are “overplayed”. How much power Saudi has left regarding coordinating supply cuts from OPEC+ remains up for debate, after the latest OPEC+ meeting proved to be a struggle to ensure supply cut commitments from all members (especially Russia). However, fellow OPEC member UAE echoed Saudi’s comments later in the session, saying that it will continue to support actions that balance the oil market. Elsewhere, and also providing support to the crude complex, China’s July trade data showed a 14% increase in crude imports (compared to July 2018), despite a weaker Yuan.

* S&P 500 1.9% AT 2938, NASDAQ-100 2.3% AT 7725, DOW JONES 1.4% AT 26381; S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 2%, Consumer Staples 1.2%, Energy 2.9%, Financials 1.7%, Health Care 1.4%, Industrials  1.7%, Information Technology 2.4%, Materials 1.9%, Telecommunication Services 2.2%, Utilities 1%.

* M&A: Symantec (SYMC) spiked over 10% with Broadcom (AVGO) close to acquiring the company, AVGO were initially lower by over 1% but closed positive. Viacom (VIAB) had earnings where they beat on both EPS and revenue, however, when asked about the CBS merger in the conference call, the co. did not comment despite source reports earlier in the week stating further announcements could be seen in the conference call. Elsewhere, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) completed its acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum (APC).

* EARNINGS: Kraft Heinz (KHC) reported Q2 earnings which beat expectations; however, the packaged foods maker was as it disclosed another USD 1.2bln write-down, adding to the USD 15bln charge it took earlier in the year. Booking Holdings (BKNG) was up on both EPS & revenue beats Monster (MNST) fell after both EPS and revenue misses.

* OTHER STOCK SPECIFICS: Advanced Macro Devices (AMD) was over 15% higher after it introduced its new Epyc server chip, which the chipmaker claims to be twice as fast as Intel’s (INTC) Cascade Lake Chip; INTC were initially lower by around 1%, however, as markets gained the stock clawed back losses and closed 1% higher; Altice (ATUS) was pressured in late trade as talks with Stonepeak reportedly collapsed, with regards to the selling of its stake in Lightpath. Sarapeta Therapeutics (SRPT) were hit after it was revealed in an FDA statement its SRP-1001 drug had safety issues. 

* FX WRAP: The dollar was knocked after Trump’s familiar criticism of the Fed and the US dollar, and the DXY heads into Asia with a slight negative bias. EUR continues to consolidate around the 1.12 area, though saw some neg ticks with the Italian government on the verge of collapse, and new elections being talked about; the bund/BTP spread blew out to over 210bps, once again exerting itself on the single currency. Havens JPY, CHF, and XAU were bid, with the yen falling sub-106, and gold retaining USD 1500, despite higher US yields and stocks trading higher. Risk sensitive currencies like the CAD, AUD, NZD bounced after reaching technically oversold levels; the RUB and NOK was also higher as crude advanced. GBP traded with an offered tone, though is back above 1.21, having fallen beneath the level after PM Johnson said he’d hold elections the day after Brexit if a no confidence emotion passed; GBP seemed, however, to be taking its cued from the USD. EMFX was also firmer amid the risk bounce and dollar weakness; BRL took cues from pension reform clearing the lower house unamended on Tuesday, while MXN, ZAR and TRY also firmed. Attention overnight will once again be on the PBOC’s yuan fix, after it was nudged to over seven for the first time since 2008 on Thursday – the fix has been quite influential on FX actions in European and US hours.

* TRY: The Lira advanced to a four-month high, positive for the seventh day in ten; the upside has been attributed to thawing relations between the US/Turkey, while pricing for Fed rate cuts has also helped support. Longer-term factors have included the declining in inflation, as well as improving current account. Technicians note that the break of USDTRY 200dma to the downside this week gives scope for a bullish Lira view, with some desks now seeing the Turkish currency closer to 5.00. Inflation has been declining, and the country seems insulated from US/China trade wars, while yield differentials are also attractive, SocGen says.

* BRL: The real firmed as pension reform clearing the lower house without amendments on Wednesday. Inflation data missed slightly, though the BRL seemed unaffected; headline IPCA was 0.19% in July vs expectations for 0.24%, the annual measure decelerated to a below target 3.22%. Core inflation was also lower than expected in July at 0.15%, while the annual core measure moderated further to 3.01%. Analysts had said that an inflation miss could leave the door open to further rate cuts from the BCB, which trimmed by a larger than expected 50bps last week.

* MXN: Mexican inflation rose in line with expectations, driven by higher fresh food and services prices. However, the Y/Y measure eased by 0.1ppts to 3.8%, and the core measure was relatively unchanged. "Headline inflation convergence to Banxico’s 3% mid-point objective proves slow as core inflation remains unresponsive to a widening output gap," Oxford Economics said, "we forecast headline inflation at 3.6% by end-19, which could help Banxico to loosen its highly restrictive monetary stance as soon as the September meeting."

"Headline inflation convergence to Banxico’s 3% mid-point objective proves slow as core inflation remains unresponsive to a widening output gap," Oxford Economics said, "we forecast headline inflation at 3.6% by end-19, which could help Banxico to loosen its highly restrictive monetary stance as soon as the September meeting."

subject: WTI (U9) settles USD 1.45 higher at USD 52.54/bbl; Brent (V9) settles USD 1.15 higher at USD 57.38
analysis_details: Oil prices were firmer on Thursday, with the market finding support after a bout of excessive selling. The bounce was catalysed not long after the energy settlement on Wednesday, when comments from Saudi Arabia suggested the OPEC kingpin is considering all options to stabilise the oil market. Earlier on Thursday, a Saudi official doubled-down, saying it is willing to do “whatever it takes” to keep the market balanced, and jawboned that the Kingdom is seeing healthy demand and that concerns are “overplayed”. How much power Saudi has left regarding coordinating supply cuts from OPEC+ remains up for debate, after the latest OPEC+ meeting proved to be a struggle to ensure supply cut commitments from all members (especially Russia). However, fellow OPEC member UAE echoed Saudi’s comments later in the session, saying that it will continue to support actions that balance the oil market. Elsewhere, and also providing support to the crude complex, China’s July trade data showed a 14% increase in crude imports (compared to July 2018), despite a weaker Yuan.

content:
* THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The US will this week sell a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a new 10-year note (USD 27bln,Wednesday), and a new 30-year bond (USD 19bln, Thursday); with USD 57.3bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, the supply will raise a net USD 26.7bln in new cash. TD Securities says that with the Fed halting balance sheet runoff at its July meeting, it will now reinvest all maturing Treasuries as add-ons at auction. TD says that with USD 54.8bln in SOMA holdings maturing at month end, the Fed will add on USD 24.8bln to 3s, USD 17.6bln to 10s, and USD 12.4bln to 30s.

Writing before the slide in yields on Tuesday, SocGen suggested that the 30-year sector was rich on asset swap versus previous auction cycles. However, on the 5s30s curve, which has steepened of late, SocGen says, though still appears cheap. SocGen says it is neutral on the auction.

Talking Crude: Energy prices firmer amid Saudi pledges
analysis_details:
• Oil prices are firmer on Thursday, with the market seemingly finding some support after a bout of excessive selling. The bounce back was catalysed not long after the energy settlement yesterday when comments out of Saudi suggested the OPEC kingpin is considering all options for the oil market. Earlier on today a Saudi official doubled down, saying it is willing to do “whatever it takes” to keep the market balanced, and jawboned that the Kingdom is seeing healthy demand and that concerns are “overplayed”. How much power Saudi has left regarding coordinating supply cuts from OPEC+ remains up for debate, after the latest OPEC+ meeting proved to be a struggle to ensure supply cut commitments from all members (especially Russia). Elsewhere and also providing support to the crude complex is China’s July trade data, which showed a 14% increase in crude imports (compared to July 2018), despite a weaker Yuan.
  • Goldman Sachs has said that given there has been no signs of oil fundamentals materially worsening, the market is pricing in “too dire a growth outlook”. On a technical basis, the bank believes that the large sell-off since last Thursday has been fuelled by negative gamma effects due to prices falling through strikes of large open interest; additionally the large move has attracted trend-following flows to further exacerbate the difference between prices and fundamentals. Goldman concluded by saying it expects prices to remain volatile until there is clear evidence that end-demand is resilient.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Antipodean Dollars extend recovery gains, other majors mixed
content:
AUD/NZD

The Aussie continues to outperform after suffering mainly bearish contagion from its Kiwi cousin on Wednesday when the RBNZ surprised with a 50 bp rate cut vs -1/4 point consensus and rammed home the message that the OCR could be reduced further from 1%, and even sub-zero, if necessary. Upbeat Chinese trade data has been the catalyst, and certainly helped to divert attention from a 7.0039 Usd/Cny PBoC fix, albeit the reference not quite as expected again, with Aud/Usd now back above 06800 and even Nzd/Usd paring more losses towards 0.6500 as Aud/Nzd hovers around 1.0500.

CAD/NOK/SEK

Firmer oil prices amidst supportive Saudi pledges has helped the Loonie shrug off weaker than expected Canadian new home sale prices, as Usd/Cad remains closer to the base of a 1.3275-1.3315 range, and also assisted the Norwegian Krona regain some poise along with a broader recovery in risk sentiment with Eur/Nok probing 10.0000 bids. However, Eur/Sek has pulled back further from Wednesday’s highs towards 10.7300 on some technical retracement.

JPY/EUR/GBP/CHF 

All on course to end Thursday’s EU session narrowly mixed vs the Greenback with the Yen still not straying too far from the 106.00 axis and Euro only briefly recovering from a sub-1.1200 decline as Bund yields spiked on reports of new German debt issuance to fund climate initiatives. Conversely, the Pound has regrouped after a stop-fuelled break below 1.2100 and Eur/Gbp spike to 0.9265 as FT reports about a possible UK General Election soon after Brexit on October 31 recirculated and spooked Sterling. Meanwhile, the Franc has lost a bit more safe-haven appeal across the board as Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf extend upside ranges to 0.9580+ and 1.0955 respectively, undoubtedly to the relief of the SNB.

EM

Mixed fortunes for the likes of the Lira, Real, Rand and Peso as Usd/Try resumed its downward trend after a fleeting pop above 5.5100 to test 5.4400 and Usd/Brl continued to cheer the passage of Brazil’s Pension Reform Bill with less arduous amendments, down through 3.9300 at one stage. In contrast, Usd/Zar rebounded from sub-15.0000 to revisit 2019 peaks just shy of 15.2000 amidst a raft of disappointing SA data, but roughly in line Mexican CPI did not impact Usd/Mxn as it hovered nearer the bottom of a 19.6520-5100 band.

Reportedly, contractors have heard sensitive conversations ranging from weight loss to relationship problems. This follows Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) and Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) recent decision to halt the use of human transcribers for their Siri and Google Assistant services, after the companies faced a similar backlash reports of “eavesdropping”.

subject: S&P says the latest proposed 10% tariffs on another USD 300bln of Chinese imports, if passed, would have a much larger impact on the US tech sector than the prior three rounds
China Global Times Editor notes encouraging China trade data, says China enterprises are adjusting and creating new export markets, adds "trade war won't crush China"
content:
• "Despite pressure of trade war, China's exports grew 3.3% in July from a year ago, beating expectation. Chinese enterprises are speeding up adjustment, creating new export markets. Chinese economy is more resilient. Trade war won't crush China."
  • Via Hu Xijin
analysis_details: NOTE our earlier analysis: The trade surplus narrowed, but the pace of export growth rose unexpectedly in July on the back of stronger exports to non-US nations. Declining exports to the US moderated a slightly, but analysts still suggest that this implies that the drag from US Tariffs continued to intensify. The decline of imports also was better than expected, which CapEco says is consistent with evidence that headwinds to the domestic economy eased. “Looking ahead, exports still look set to remain under pressure in the coming quarters as any prop from a weaker renminbi should be overshadowed by further US tariffs and broader external weakness,” according to Capital Economics, “though August exports may benefit from front-loading before the new tariffs go into effect on September 1st, this bump will probably be smaller than it was ahead of earlier rounds of tariffs as US port storage facilities have little spare capacity.” The consultancy does not think that the recent fiscal easing will be enough to prevent a renewed slowdown in domestic demand, which will likely weigh on import volumes.

ANALYSIS: China fixes yuan above 7 overnight the first time since 2008
analysis_details: China’s central bank weakened the yuan reference point, fixing it above 7.00 against the USD for the first time since 2008, although was not weakened as much as some models had foreseen. The market has been eying the fix for insight on what constitutes a ‘comfortable’ level for the PBOC. UBS notes that although the PBOC has stepped up measures to slow the yuan’s pace of depreciation (including: introducing a larger counter cyclical factor, issuing central bank bills in Hong Kong to manage liquidity, pledging to keep the yuan stable) the market remain concerned about further weakening. “Today’s fixing is a clear message that China doesn’t mind letting its currency depreciate beyond any specific number, but would like to control the pace it weakens and mitigate market volatility as ‘stability’, which is PBoC governor Yi Gang's main goal.” The bank believes that upward pressure on USDCNH is likely to persist in the near-term.

subject: Pakistan Foreign Minister says Pakistan his country is not looking at military options over the Kashmir dispute
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmer thus far, as risk sentiment remained positive after a upbeat Asia-Pac session following strong Chinese data and a firmer than expected CNY reference rate
  • Saudi official says it plans to keep its production below 10mln BPD, committed to do what ever it takes to keep the oil market balanced
  • Dollar is generally softer vs. G10 counterparts, with antipodeans outperforming on the China data though NZD has been impacted by dovish comments from RBNZ Hawkesby
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Initial Jobless Claims & Wholesale Inventory, Canadian Housing Price Index, US 30yr Auction
  • Earnings: Viacom & Activision Blizzard

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets gained as a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting and Chinese trade data helped the region shake off the initial tentativeness following the tumultuous day on Wall St, where stocks staged a dramatic intraday recovery and although the DJIA closed in the red, it posted its largest rebound YTD. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was initially subdued amid losses in its top weighted financials sector following earnings from AMP Capital and Insurance Australia Group but then conformed to the improved risk tone led by gold miners after the precious metal rallied above USD 1500/oz for the first time since 2013, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by currency flows and KOSPI (+0.6%) outperformed after Japan approved some exports of tech materials to South Korea for the first time since curbs were imposed last month. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were positive with sentiment underpinned by relief after the PBoC announced the reference rate which was set beyond the 7.0000 level for the first time since 2008 but not as weak as expected, while participants also digested Chinese trade data which topped estimates across the board and still showed a significant, albeit narrower imbalance in US-China trade. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower with mild pressure seen amid the improved risk tone in the region, although prices then returned flat with support seen amid firmer demand at the 10yr inflation-indexed auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0039 vs. Exp. 7.0205 (Prev. 6.9996)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Jul) 45.1B vs. Exp. 43.20B (Prev. 50.98B). Chinese Exports (USD)(Jul) Y/Y 3.3% vs. Exp. -2.0% (Prev. -1.3%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Jul) Y/Y -5.6% vs. Exp. -9.0% (Prev. -7.3%)

China Trade Surplus with US in July at USD 27.97bln vs. Prev. 29.92bln M/M.

South Korea PM Lee confirmed that Japan has granted export approval of one of the high-tech materials to South Korea for the first time since restrictions were imposed in July, while Japanese Industry Minister Seko warned if improper use of exports to South Korea is discovered, will consider widening the strict examinations beyond the 3 high-tech materials. Furthermore, it was later reported that South Korea is to hold off on plan of removing Japan from its white list. (Newswires)

China's Securities and Regulatory Vice Chairman says the impact of US pressure on China's stock market is weakening. (Newswires)

US

Major banks have given congressional committees investigating US President Trump thousands of pages of documents, which refer to the Presidents potential dealings with Russians., WSJ

- Banks include, Deutsche Bank (DBK GY), CitiGroup (CITI), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) & Wells Fargo (WFC)

GEOPOLITICS

India urges Pakistan to review its diplomatic ties downgrade with New Delhi, according to a government statement. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly could call for a general election on November 1st which is one day after the Brexit, to get a boost from Leave supporters as he would be able to tell them he has delivered on the Brexit. (The Sun)

UK Foreign Minister Raab said if the EU believes there can be no changes to the Brexit agreement, "that makes it very hard to see how we can move negotiations forward". In other news, Foreign Minister Raab stated that US President Trump has huge appetite for a free trade agreement with UK, while US Secretary of State Pompeo also said the US is ready to sign a UK-US trade deal after Brexit and that he discussed 5G issues with Raab. (Newswires/Sky News)

Leader of the Opposition Corbyn will go to Buckingham Palace in a taxi to tell the Queen “we’re taking over” if PM Johnson loses a vote of no confidence, Shadow Chancellor McDonnell has said. (Times)

UK RICS Housing Survey (Jul) -9 vs. Exp. -1.0 (Prev. -1.0). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European stocks are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +1.1%], following on from a positive Asia-Pac handover after optimistic Chinese trade data lifted sentiment in the region. Indices are posting broad-based gains, although UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.1%) lags its peers amid a slew of large cap ex-divs. Sectors are also in positive territory, although defensive sectors are somewhat lagging. Looking at individual movers, Adidas (-1.3%) shares opened lower by over 2% as investors for weeks sought an upgrade to guidance, particularly after its rival Puma (+2.5%) raised its sales and profit forecasts recently. Sticking with the DAX, Thyssenkrupp (+3.3%) shares rose despite an EBIT guidance cut as investors shifted focus to its elevator division IPO (expected in FY19/20) and expression of interests for other divisions. Finally, Osram Licht (-6.6%) slumped to the foot of the Stoxx 600 after the Co’s largest shareholder rejected the EUR 3.4bln takeover offer form Bain & Carlyle. It’s also worth noting that Goldman Sachs has downgraded trade sensitive sectors (EU autos and basic resources) in light of the recent developments between US and China, although individual stocks are little swayed by the broker update.

Russian anti-monopoly watchdog has opened an investigation into Apple (AAPL) regarding operating system applications following complaints from Kaspersky Lab , according to RIA

FX

USD - The Dollar is on a softer footing against its G10 rivals, and most EMs amidst another revival in broad risk appetite, prompted in part by Chinese trade data that beat consensus across all key components and offset or appeased concerns over the ongoing incline in the Usd/Cny reference rate. However, the index is still straddling 97.500 and from a technical perspective holding above key Fib support at 97.392 on a closing basis, if not intraday, and it remains to be seen if the latest upturn in sentiment proves more sustainable or transitory like on Tuesday.

AUD/NZD/GBP/CAD - In keeping with the improved risk tone noted above, Aud/Usd has turned full circle and a bit more from midweek session lows towards 0.6800, but unlikely at this stage to reach hefty expiry options residing between 0.6840-50 (1.2 bn), while Nzd/Usd is still underperforming within 0.6468-35 parameters following more dovish RBNZ rhetoric on balance after yesterday’s double-barrelled ½ point OCR cut. Elsewhere, Cable is back around 1.2150 and the Loonie has rebounded through 1.3300 along side crude prices ahead of Canadian house price data.

JPY/EUR/CHF/XAU - The safer-havens are off best levels, but interestingly and perhaps tellingly still relatively bid as the Yen contains losses below 106.00 to circa 106.30 with decent option expiry interest likely to cap further upside in Usd/Jpy given 1 bn running off from 106.45-55. Similarly, the single currency is holding above 1.1200, but also likely to be stymied by expiries as 2.4 bn awaits between 1.1230-40, while the latest ECB monthly bulletin is far from Euro supportive given a downbeat assessment of the Eurozone economy and outlook, albeit largely a repetition of President Draghi’s post-policy meeting text. Elsewhere, the Franc is pivoting 0.9750 and Gold is rangebound either side of Usd1500/oz.

EM - The Rand continues to underperform with Usd/Zar mostly above 15.0000 after recent technical breaks to the upside and with weaker than forecast SA mining data not helping.

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said outlook for rates is more balanced after 50bps cut but added there is still some probability OCR will need to be reduced further, while Hawkesby also stated the central bank are watching inflation expectations closely and that unconventional tools are a contingency in the event inflation tanks although they would need to exhaust conventional policy tools first. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expires:

- EUR/USD: 1.1100 (1BLN), 1.1125 (2.8BLN), 1.1160 (500M), 1.1175-85 (600M) 1.1230-40 (2.4BLN), 1.1245-50 (700M), 1.1275-85 (1BLN)

- USD/JPY: 105.00 (1BLN), 105.50 (1BLN), 106.00 (923M), 106.20-25 (650M), 106.45-55 (1BLN), 106.80 (400M), 107.35-40 (800M), 107.50 (2.5BLN

FIXED INCOME

The bond narrative hasn’t changed much for the session thus far, as the markets haven’t received any further updates on the geopolitical/trade front, or much more data/headlines to potentially impact direction. Hence, the 'trend' remains the same after the pullback across the fixed complex, albeit less deep, with some sporadic upward momentum evident via Gilts printing a marginal new Liffe intraday high at 134.15 earlier. Meanwhile, Bunds are still hovering just shy of 177.00 in wake of the ECB’s Economic Bulletin that was largely in-line with the statement after July's policy meeting, but provided no further guidance next month's high stakes convene. Turning to the periphery, BTPs continue to underperform on renewed/heightened political friction and Friday’s Fitch rating call, while Stateside Treasuries are off overnight lows, but still unwinding recent bull-flattening awaiting further US-China developments and with one eye on initial jobless claims before the final auction of the week. On that note, after a softish 2 year sale Wednesday's 10 year results were weak so it will be interesting to see whether long bonds are deemed more attractive given the concession compared to yesterday's yield compression. 

 

COMMODITIES

A day of consolidation for the oil complex thus far after yesterday’s wave of downside in which the benchmarks declined almost 5% as demand concerns continue to materialise. WTI and Brent prices have rebounded off worst levels and reside around 52.23/bbl and 57.14/bbl respectively at the time of writing (vs. yesterday’s lows of 50.55/bbl and 55.90/bbl). The recent trade-induced sell-off has caught the attention of Saudi officials who are reportedly looking at options to stem the decline in the oil market.  At the moment, no details of potential actions were mentioned, although desks note that anything else other than compliance control and further output cuts could be unrealistic, even then, reaching an OPEC+ consensus on further curbs could prove difficult given the debacle at the June meeting between the producers. Nonetheless, the media reports have seemingly underpinned the benchmarks for now. Elsewhere gold prices are tentative, albeit off its 6-year peak of 1510/oz and back below the psychological figure. Protectionism risk remains in the forefront for the yellow metal with trade sources noting that China expects the 10% levy on Chinese goods to be implemented on September 1 and thereafter be ramped up to 25% as China stands firm. Meanwhile, copper prices are flat on the day amid the cautiousness in the market, although the red metal did receive some short-lived impetus to test 2.60/lb to the upside as Chinese trade data topped estimates across the board, however, iron ore prices failed to benefit from the data amid ongoing supply glut and lower demand concerns. Finally, nickel prices surged over 10% overnight due to speculation that Indonesia could reel in an export ban on nickel ore in a regulatory move, although an official announcement is yet to be made.

Saudi official says it plans to keep its production below 10mln BPD, committed to do what ever it takes to keep the oil market balanced. (Newswires)

Indonesia played down rumours of a nickel import ban and said it is to revoke permits if smelter targets are not met. (Newswires)

subject: Saudi official says it plans to keep its August production below 10mln BPD (July production stood at 9.65mln BPD), committed to do what ever it takes to keep the oil market balanced
content:
• Says September nominations will fall by 700k BPD from August levels
  • Plans to keep its August and September exports below 7mln BPD
  • Says its August oil nominations were 700k BPD above July, which it says is a sign of healthy demand
  • Says recent oil demand concerns are "overplayed" and reflect bad macroeconomic sentiment
  • Says oil market fundamentals are strong, especially on the supply side due to OPEC+ cuts and lowering US output growth outlook
analysis_details: • This is a doubling down of Saudi comments yesterday in which it said it was considering all options for the oil market. However, with existing OPEC+ supply cuts already in-place, it begs the question of how much firepower OPEC (let alone OPEC+) has left to give in regard to further supply cuts, especially given the difficulties the cartel faced in coming to a collective decision at their last meeting; Saudi could potentially have to make lone efforts at further cuts if it can't gain collaboration from other members.

Meanwhile, Bunds are still hovering just shy of 177.00 in wake of the ECB’s Economic Bulletin that was largely in-line with the statement after July's policy meeting, but provided no further guidance next month's high stakes convene. Turning to the periphery, BTPs continue to underperform on renewed/heightened political friction and Friday’s Fitch rating call, while Stateside Treasuries are off overnight lows, but still unwinding recent bull-flattening awaiting further US-China developments and with one eye on initial jobless claims before the final auction of the week. On that note, after a softish 2 year sale Wednesday's 10 year results were weak so it will be interesting to see whether long bonds are deemed more attractive given the concession compared to yesterday's yield compression.

subject: Nomura: Rebound in US stocks seen as a mere technical rally
content:
• If key market indices fail to climb back above trend-chasers' major trigger lines (at around 2,960 for the S&P 500 and around 7,720 for the NASDAQ 100), then Nomura would expect trend-followers that are currently sitting on unrealized losses (including CTAs) to start exiting their long positions in equities at a quickening pace.  
  • Nomura see the rebound in US stocks as a mere technical rally that looks like no more than a bump in the road on the way down.  
  • Stock market sentiment, both in the US and globally, is parked well into negative territory. This evidence of risk-avoiding sentiment among investors implies that risk appetite has eroded substantially.  
  • Contrarian buying at the moment is probably being led by 1) ultra-short-term investors (with investment horizons of around 10 days) targeting a near-term reversal, and 2) global macro hedge funds that are still bullish on fundamentals. Among systematic trend-chasers, however, CTAs stand ready to sell.  
  • Loss-cutting exits from long positions by CTAs will probably remain the order of the day for as long as the S&P 500 is below 2,960 and the NASDAQ 100 is below 7,720.  
  • Currently, CTAs are tilted towards buying UST futures (TY) and a broad range of other DM country bond futures, and their net long positions in these instruments have grown.

subject: FX Morning Colour: a little less fixation on PBoC manipulation
content:
USD

The Dollar is on a softer footing against its G10 rivals, and most EMs amidst another revival in broad risk appetite, prompted in part by Chinese trade data that beat consensus across all key components and offset or appeased concerns over the ongoing incline in the Usd/Cny reference rate. However, the index is still straddling 97.500 and from a technical perspective holding above key Fib support at 97.392 on a closing basis, if not intraday, and it remains to be seen if the latest upturn in sentiment proves more sustainable or transitory like on Tuesday.

AUD/NZD/GBP/CAD

In keeping with the improved risk tone noted above, Aud/Usd has turned full circle and a bit more from midweek session lows towards 0.6800, but unlikely at this stage to reach hefty expiry options residing between 0.6840-50 (1.2 bn), while Nzd/Usd is still underperforming within 0.6468-35 parameters following more dovish RBNZ rhetoric on balance after yesterday’s double-barrelled ½ point OCR cut. Elsewhere, Cable is back around 1.2150 and the Loonie has rebounded through 1.3300 along side crude prices ahead of Canadian house price data.

JPY/EUR/CHF/XAU 

The safer-havens are off best levels, but interestingly and perhaps tellingly still relatively bid as the Yen contains losses below 106.00 to circa 106.30 with decent option expiry interest likely to cap further upside in Usd/Jpy given 1 bn running off from 106.45-55. Similarly, the single currency is holding above 1.1200, but also likely to be stymied by expiries as 2.4 bn awaits between 1.1230-40, while the latest ECB monthly bulletin is far from Euro supportive given a downbeat assessment of the Eurozone economy and outlook, albeit largely a repetition of President Draghi’s post-policy meeting text. Elsewhere, the Franc is pivoting 0.9750 and Gold is rangebound either side of Usd1500/oz.

EM 

The Rand continues to underperform with Usd/Zar mostly above 15.0000 after recent technical breaks to the upside and with weaker than forecast SA mining data not helping.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures recoil alongside core counterparts
content: A more pronounced pull-back in Bunds and US Treasuries ahead of the Liffe open took its toll on Gilts and piled a bit more pressure on already depressed Short Sterling contracts. The 10 year UK benchmark was marked down 37 ticks initially at 134.06, but quickly relinquished the 134.00 handle on its way down to 133.89 before finding some underlying bids, while the 3 month strip has also pared losses from -1 to -5.5 ticks at worst to stand +0.5/-3 ticks around Wednesday’s settlement levels at present. No UK data or events scheduled for today, but a busy agenda tomorrow, so direction will be derived from elsewhere and dependent to large extent on whether or how long the current improved risk tone lasts.

Bunds: pendulum swings back in favour of risk assets, for now at least
content: Core bonds and other safe-havens have retreated relatively sharply from Wednesday’s highs on the back of another recovery in risk sentiment, as stronger than expected Chinese trade data and an impressive Wall St revival overshadow the much vaunted 7.0000+ PBoC mid-point fix. Meanwhile, Italian BTPs are also factoring in renewed political premium within a 141.00-140.21 range vs yesterday’s 141.48 close as Rome’s coalition Government appears back on the brink of collapse ahead of Friday’s ratings review from Fitch. However, this underperformance is not really feeding into Bunds that remain below 177.00 compared to 177.19 at best and the 177.36 midweek session settlement, albeit off 176.68 lows. Ahead, the ECB monthly bulletin could give Eurozone debt a boost, if dovish as widely anticipated.

ASIA

ASX 200 (+0.5%) was initially subdued amid losses in its top weighted financials sector following earnings from AMP Capital and Insurance Australia Group but then conformed to the improved risk tone led by gold miners after the precious metal rallied above USD 1500/oz for the first time since 2013, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was underpinned by currency flows and KOSPI (+1.0%) outperformed after Japan approved some exports of tech materials to South Korea for the first time since curbs were imposed last month. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets gained as a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting and Chinese trade data helped the region shake off initial tentativeness
  • DXY flatlined during Asian hours with price action stuck around 97.50 and with uneventful trade observed across its major counterparts
  • UK PM Johnson reportedly could call for a general election on November 1st (one day after Brexit), to get a boost from Leave supporters
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims & Wholesale Inventory, Canadian Housing Price Index, US 30yr Auction
  • Earnings: Viacom, Activision Blizzard, Adidas, Deutsche Telekom, ThyssenKrupp, Hargreaves Lansdown

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets gained as a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting and Chinese trade data helped the region shake off the initial tentativeness following the tumultuous day on Wall St, where stocks staged a dramatic intraday recovery and although the DJIA closed in the red, it posted its largest rebound YTD. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was initially subdued amid losses in its top weighted financials sector following earnings from AMP Capital and Insurance Australia Group but then conformed to the improved risk tone led by gold miners after the precious metal rallied above USD 1500/oz for the first time since 2013, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was underpinned by currency flows and KOSPI (+0.9%) outperformed after Japan approved some exports of tech materials to South Korea for the first time since curbs were imposed last month. Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were positive with sentiment underpinned by relief after the PBoC announced the reference rate which was set beyond the 7.0000 level for the first time since 2008 but not as weak as expected, while participants also digested Chinese trade data which topped estimates across the board and still showed a significant, albeit narrower imbalance in US-China trade. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower with mild pressure seen amid the improved risk tone in the region, although prices then returned flat with support seen amid firmer demand at the 10yr inflation-indexed auction.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0039 vs. Exp. 7.0205 (Prev. 6.9996)

 

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Jul) 45.1B vs. Exp. 43.20B (Prev. 50.98B). Chinese Exports (USD)(Jul) Y/Y 3.3% vs. Exp. -2.0% (Prev. -1.3%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Jul) Y/Y -5.6% vs. Exp. -9.0% (Prev. -7.3%)

China Trade Surplus with US in July at USD 27.97bln vs. Prev. 29.92bln M/M.

 

China trade sources said China expects that the 10% tariffs will be implemented on September 1st and expects the tariffs to rise to 25% due to China "standing firm" and not purchasing US agricultural products, according to Fox News' Lawrence. (Twitter/Fox)

 

China Global Times Editor tweeted that Washington’s repeated bullying has made it meaningless to continue trade talks in the short run and that the sides are caught in a stalemate worse than the last round, while he added that China is mobilizing internally to fight firmly with the US and all official media is participating in the mobilization. (Twitter)

 

South Korea PM Lee confirmed that Japan has granted export approval of one of the high-tech materials to South Korea for the first time since restrictions were imposed in July, while Japanese Industry Minister Seko warned if improper use of exports to South Korea is discovered, will consider widening the strict examinations beyond the 3 high-tech materials. Furthermore, it was later reported that South Korea is to hold off on plan of removing Japan from its white list. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly could call for a general election on November 1st which is one day after the Brexit, to get a boost from Leave supporters as he would be able to tell them he has delivered on the Brexit. (The Sun)

 

UK Foreign Minister Raab said if the EU believes there can be no changes to the Brexit agreement, "that makes it very hard to see how we can move negotiations forward". In other news, Foreign Minister Raab stated that US President Trump has huge appetite for a free trade agreement with UK, while US Secretary of State Pompeo also said the US is ready to sign a UK-US trade deal after Brexit and that he discussed 5G issues with Raab. (Newswires/Sky News)

Three UK MP’s have, in the context of preventing UK PM Johnson from pushing through a no-deal, have reportedly stated that a method under discussion is for members to amend the necessary motion for Parliament to break in order to accommodate mid-September party conferences; providing MP’s with up to 3 weeks more sitting time. (Guardian)

Leader of the Opposition Corbyn will go to Buckingham Palace in a taxi to tell the Queen “we’re taking over” if PM Johnson loses a vote of no confidence, Shadow Chancellor McDonnell has said. (Times)

 

UK RICS Housing Survey (Jul) -9 vs. Exp. -1.0 (Prev. -1.0). (Newswires)

 

FX

 

DXY flatlined during Asia hours with price action stuck around 97.50 and with uneventful trade observed across its major counterparts including EUR/USD which found a base at 1.1200 and with mild gains seen in GBP/USD as it oscillated within the prior day’s tight range, despite a latest poll suggesting it could slip to between 1.1700-1.2000 in the run up to the Brexit and that odds of a disorderly Brexit increased to 35% from 30%. USD/JPY was choppy but well off this week’s lows with support holding at 106.00 and antipodeans nursed recent losses in which AUD/USD recouped all of the prior day’s RBNZ-induced slump as it found solace from the improved risk tone and in tandem with a firmer than expected CNY fix. Conversely, NZD/USD still has far to go for a full recovery as bank officials kept the door open for additional rate cuts in which RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby noted the outlook for rates is more balanced after the 50bps cut but added there is still some probability OCR will need to be reduced further.

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said outlook for rates is more balanced after 50bps cut but added there is still some probability OCR will need to be reduced further, while Hawkesby also stated the central bank are watching inflation expectations closely and that unconventional tools are a contingency in the event inflation tanks although they would need to exhaust conventional policy tools first. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher amid the improved risk sentiment which helped WTI crude futures recoup a majority of the yesterday’s near-5% drop to briefly below the USD 51.00/bbl that was largely attributed to the initial bearish sentiment in the US as well as a surprise build in EIA crude inventories. Nonetheless, WTI has recovered to firmly above USD 52.00/bbl with the energy complex underpinned overnight amid a turnaround in risk appetite and with Saudi said to be mulling options to support oil prices. Elsewhere, gold was flat with prices choppy around the 1500/oz at it remained at its highest levels in 6 years, while copper was underpinned by the improvement in sentiment and after better than expected Chinese trade data.

 

Saudi official said they are considering all options to stop the oil price fall and are in talks with producers to stem the slide in oil prices. (Newswires)

Indonesia played down rumours of a nickel import ban and said it is to revoke permits if smelter targets are not met. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he is hopeful that talks with North Korea will resume and that negotiations are being planned for in a few weeks. (Newswires) 

US

Yields were lower across the curve, but major curve spreads were mixed, though hadn’t deviated by more than 2bps on the session. There was far more attention on the 3m/10-year spread, which inverted to over 40bps as global yields sank, taking the spread to the most inverted since 2007. Inspiring today’s price action was risk-off flows, as China fixed the yuan weaker, and RBNZ and RBI cut rates by more than expected, with the former citing the impact of global trade on its economy, and suggesting that NIRP could be an option ahead. Fed pricing on Wednesday was relatively unchanged looking through to the end of next year, where around 109bps of easing is priced. Fed’s Evans (dove, voter) hinted at more accommodation ahead, like his dovish colleague Bullard did early in the week, but was pushing a data-dependent line with regards to the September meeting – the implication is that all FOMC participants that have spoken this week have not explicitly alluded to a rate cut on 18th September, although they have not leaned back against market pricing, which is pricing 35bps of easing, suggesting that the market is still pricing a small chance of a double-barrel rate cut. Back to the Treasury complex, yields have pared back more than half of their fall, and it seems the driving factor was the aforementioned 3m/10-year spread coming off lows. US T-note futures (U9) settled 12+ ticks higher at 130-05.

Fed's Evans (Voter, Dove) said the July cut was justified on the basis of low US inflation alone and that more accommodation is warranted, especially given economic headwinds. Evans added that brinkmanship trade negotiations means volatility and that close attention has to be paid, while he sees "mid-cycle adjustment" where the Fed is now targeting a rate 50bps below neutral, instead of 50bps above and sees long-run neutral rate as 2.75%, but may be lower now due to headwinds. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks traded higher on relief from firmer than expected CNY reference rate and Chinese trade data
content: Asia equity markets gained as a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting and Chinese trade data helped the region shake off the initial tentativeness following the tumultuous day on Wall St, where stocks staged a dramatic intraday recovery and although the DJIA closed in the red, it posted its largest rebound YTD. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was initially subdued amid losses in its top weighted financials sector following earnings from AMP Capital and Insurance Australia Group but then conformed to the improved risk tone led by gold miners after the precious metal rallied above USD 1500/oz for the first time since 2013, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was underpinned by currency flows and KOSPI (+1.0%) outperformed after Japan approved some exports of tech materials to South Korea for the first time since curbs were imposed last month. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were positive with sentiment underpinned by relief after the PBoC announced the reference rate which was set beyond the 7.0000 level for the first time since 2008 but not as weak as expected, while participants also digested Chinese trade data which topped estimates across the board and still showed a significant, albeit narrower imbalance in US-China trade. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower with mild pressure seen amid the improved risk tone in the region, although prices then returned flat with support seen amid firmer demand at the 10yr inflation-indexed auction.

Other News - Pakistan announced to expel the India ambassador and suspended trade with the country after India scrapped Kashmir’s autonomy. (Newswires)

RBI - RBI cut the Repurchase Rate by 35bps to 5.40% and cut the Reverse Repo Rate by 35bps to 5.15% vs. Exp. 25bps cut for both and maintained its accommodative monetary policy stance. RBI stated all members voted unanimously to cut rates, as well as keep stance unchanged in which 4 members voted for a 35bps cut and 2 voted for a 25bps cut. RBI revised 2019/20 GDP growth to 6.9% vs. Prev. 7.0%, sees headline inflation at 3.1% in Q2 FY20, 3.5%-3.7% in H2 FY20 and inflation to remain within target over a 12-month timeline. Furthermore, RBI Governor Das said the RBI has been pre-emptive in policy action and stance, that growth concerns assume the highest priority as inflation is within the target, while he added that a 50bp cut would have been excessive and the board took a balanced view. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade higher on relief from a firmer than expected CNY reference rate, but with gains capped ahead of Chinese trade data
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly higher as a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting helped the region shake off the initial tentativeness ahead of Chinese trade data and after the tumultuous day on Wall St, where stocks staged a dramatic intraday recovery in which the DJIA closed in the red but posted its largest rebound YTD. ASX 200 was initially subdued amid losses in its top weighted financials sector following earnings from AMP Capital and Insurance Australia Group but then conformed to the improved risk tone led by gold miners after the precious metal rallied above USD 1500/oz for the first time since 2013, while Nikkei 225 is underpinned by currency flows and KOSPI outperforms after Japan approved some exports of tech materials to South Korea for the first time since curbs were imposed last month. Elsewhere, Hang Seng and Shanghai Comp. are positive with sentiment in the region underpinned by relief after the PBoC announced the reference rate which was set beyond the 7.0000 level for the first time since 2008 but not as weak as expected, while focus now turns to the looming Chinese trade data.

In FX markets, the DXY flatlined during Asia hours with price action stuck around the 97.50 level and with uneventful trade observed across its major counterparts including EUR/USD which found a base at 1.1200 and with mild gains seen in GBP/USD as it oscillates within the prior day’s tight range, despite a latest poll suggesting it could slip to between 1.1700-1.2000 in the run up to the Brexit and that odds of a disorderly Brexit increased to 35% from 30%. Elsewhere, antipodeans nurse recent losses in which AUD/USD briefly recouped all of the prior day’s RBNZ-induced slump as it found solace from the improved risk tone and in tandem with a firmer than expected CNY fix, while NZD/USD still has far to go for a full recovery as bank officials kept the door open for additional cuts in which RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby noted the outlook for rates is more balanced after the 50bps cut but added there is still some probability OCR will need to be reduced further.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally lower with mild pressure seen amid the improved risk tone in the region and with participants sidelined ahead of a 10yr inflation-indexed auction.

Trade

US President Trump's administration is reportedly going to unveil a rule today that bans agencies from directly purchasing telecom, video surveillance equipment or services from Huawei, ZTE and Hikvision which will take effect on August 13th, while a second rule for broader part of ban on federal contracts with companies that use telecom equipment from Chinese firms is to take effect August 2020. (CNBC)

China trade sources said China expects that the 10% tariffs will be implemented on September 1st and also expect the tariffs to rise to 25% due to China "standing firm" and not purchasing US agricultural products, according to Fox News' Lawrence. (Twitter/Fox)

A video conference has reportedly been planned to lay the groundwork for next round of US-China face to face talks according to SCMP citing sources briefed by the US government, while former Vice-Minister of Commerce responsible for foreign trade Wei Jianguo said it is possible that the meeting could ease the tensions a bit on some aspects but declined to elaborate further. (SCMP)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that Washington’s repeated bullying has made it meaningless to continue trade talks in the short run and that the sides are caught in a stalemate worse than the last round, while he added that China is mobilizing internally to fight firmly with the US and all official media is participating in the mobilization. (Twitter)

China is reportedly mulling new measures to stabilize trade. (Newswires)
